awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Evolution of Endocrine Function; Discovering the Hormonal Control of Osmoregulation in Basal Vertebrates
awd_abstract_narration:
All living organisms must regulate their internal salt and water content to function routinely and survive.  In more complex animals, such as vertebrates, hormones and the receptors to which they bind are critical signaling molecules involved in regulation of salt and water transport.  Fish are in direct contact with water, and they must actively take up salts from freshwater and actively secrete them in seawater to be able to regulate internal salt concentrations.  To date research on the hormonal control of salt regulation has been limited to studies on advanced fish species.  This project will examine the hormonal control of salt regulation in two basal vertebrates, lamprey eel and sturgeon.  The researchers will examine how growth hormone and prolactin, two hormones secreted by the pituitary gland, and their receptors are altered by external salinity. This research will determine the effect of these hormones on the ability of lamprey and sturgeon to tolerate changes in external salinity.  The results of these studies will yield insights about the functional evolution of these hormones, which in turn could be applied to enhancing agricultural production of fish and management of invasive lamprey.  The results will be rapidly transferred to textbooks in comparative endocrinology and physiology, published in peer-reviewed journals, and shared at scientific meetings. 

Studies supported by this award will investigate the functional evolution of osmoregulatory hormones in aquatic vertebrates. Our current understanding of the hormonal control of osmoregulation in aquatic vertebrates comes almost entirely from advanced bony fish (teleosts), and there is no information on how pituitary hormones control osmoregulation in basal vertebrates. It is now well-established that prolactin (PRL) is critical for survival of most teleosts in freshwater (FW) and that growth hormone (GH), at least in some lineages, promotes osmoregulation in seawater (SW). Lamprey, as basal vertebrates, and chondrosteans (including sturgeon), as basal bony fish, have the same osmoregulatory strategy as teleosts (namely, maintaining nearly constant levels of plasma ions irrespective of external salinity), yet there is currently no information on whether PRL or GH play a role in osmoregulation of either lamprey or chondrosteans. There is strong evidence that lamprey possess only one member of the PRL/GH family of pituitary hormones (GH), making them especially critical for these studies. Our specific aims are: 1) to determine the response of GH and GH receptor to salinity change in lamprey; 2) to determine the osmoregulatory actions of GH in lamprey; and 3) to determine the osmoregulatory roles of GH and PRL in sturgeon. For each species we will examine the time course of physiological and endocrine responses to reciprocal transfers between FW and SW.  We will utilize recombinant technology to make lamprey GH in order to develop homologous radioimmuno- and radioreceptor- assays, and determine its osmoregulatory actions in vivo and in vitro.

por.por_cntn:
Lamprey are representatives of the oldest extant vertebrate lineage called Agnatha, having diverged from other vertebrate lineages approximately 550 million years ago. Lamprey, like humans, regulate their internal salt balance at one-third of seawater (SW). In freshwater (FW)  lamprey passively lose ions and gain water and counteract this by actively take up ions across the gill. On the other hand, when in SW the gill must secrete ions. However, the specific ion transporters involved in sea lamprey osmoregulation are largely unknown. Hormones play a critical role in controlling osmoregulation in vertebrates. In teleosts, it is known that prolactin and growth hormone promote osmoregulation in FW and SW, respectively. Cortisol works synergistically with these hormones, enhancing their action. However, little is known on how these hormones act to control osmoregulation in lamprey.  

 

We demonstrated that  11-deoxycortisol (rather than cortisol) is the primary corticosteroid involved in the control of sea lamprey osmoregulation. We found that plasma 11-deoxycortisol and its receptor in the gill increase during metamorphosis when salinity tolerance develops. Lamprey injected with 11-deoxycortisol had increased activity of gill and intestine ion transporters, which improved SW tolerance. These studies demonstrate that corticosteroid control of osmoregulation is an evolutionarily basal trait in vertebrates. We have also shown that 11-deoxycortisol acts as a stress hormone. When lamprey are stressed, plasma 11-deoxycortisol and plasma glucose levels increased concurrently, and treatment with 11-deoxycortisol increases plasma glucose and activates glucose-producing genes in the liver.  These are the first studies to provide direct evidence that corticosteroid control of gluconeogenesis occurred prior to the divergence of jawed vertebrates.

 

We also characterized two genes orthologous to gnathostome growth hormone (GH) and prolactin receptors in sea lamprey. Based on the phylogenetic analysis and gene structure, it is now thought that these receptors arose in the vertebrate lineage before the divergence of lamprey. In this project we characterized the GH/IGF axis in the context of the sea lamprey life cycle, focusing on metamorphosis and  SW exposure. Our results indicate that metamorphosis is a critical point in the life cycle of sea lamprey for stimulation of the GH/IGF axis and is temporally associated with and likely promotes the development of salt secretory mechanisms  and SW tolerance. This work supports the hypothesis that the emergence of a GH/IGF axis is involved in development, metamorphosis, and osmoregulation in vertebrates was present prior to the divergence between the agnathans and gnathostomes lineages.

 

In addition to studying the hormonal control of osmoregulation, we have characterized the role of the gill and intestine in osmoregulation of sea lamprey. We characterized three ion transporters involved in osmoregulation, Na+:K+:2Cl- cotransporter (NKCC), the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), and Na+:Cl- cotransporter (NCC). We found that NKCC was primarily observed in the gill, increased with metamorphosis, and increased further after SW acclimation, providing evidence for its role ion secretion at the gill. ENaC has been found in high abundance in the gill of FW sea lamprey and is co-localized with NKA, providing evidence of a role in ion uptake. Two orthologs of NCC, NCCa and NCCb, were identified from the lamprey genome. NCCa had highest transcript levels in gill and kidney from lamprey acclimated to FW, while NCCb transcript levels were greatest in intestine and kidney from lamprey acclimated to SW. Furthermore, we have shown regionalization of the ion- and water-absorptive processes in the gut. In addition to this, using electrophysiology to functionally elucidate the underlying osmoregulatory mechanisms in the intestine, it was determined that an indapamide-sensitive transporter (NCCb) plays a role in ion absorption in the intestine. 

 

This work has been widely presented nationally and internationally by undergraduates, graduates, postdoctoral researchers and the PI (more than 20 presentations). We have published nine peer-reviewed papers and have three under review. We are currently preparing eight additional manuscripts to report findings in hormonal control of osmoregulation in sea lamprey.

 

Training undergraduates,  graduate students and postdoctoral fellows was a key component of  this project. One undergraduate summer intern was trained in molecular endocrinology using project funds. Two undergraduate students received Five Colleges Coastal and Marine Science Certificates through training and laboratory research. Four undergraduates completed Honors Theses through work completed in physiology, endocrinology, genetics, and bioinformatics. One international Ph.D. candidate received training under this project and two Ph.D. students received support over the project duration.

 

We developed a website to aid in data management between collaborative universities and to share multimedia information on evolutionary physiology and endocrinology with the general public. Two graduate students participated in a STEM mentoring program at the University of Massachusetts Amherst that aimed at increasing diversity and retention for those traditionally underrepresented while also providing research, academic, and social skills geared toward STEM fields.
